content: Clara recently started her PhD with Ryan. Her research interests include neural machine translation and robustness in AI-based systems. In her free time, she likes to rock climb and trail run.
summary: Clara recently started her PhD with Ryan. Her research interests include neural machine translation and robustness in AI-based systems. In her free time, she likes to rock climb and trail run.
title: Clara Meister

content: Edoardo is a third-year Ph.D. student in Computational Linguistics at the University of Cambridge, where he is part of St John’s College. He is supervised by Prof. Anna Korhonen and funded through the ERC project LEXICAL. He has previously interned as an AI/ML researcher at Apple in Cupertino, and been awarded a Google Research Faculty Award for a project co-written with his supervisor. His research focuses on few-shot multilingual learning and on the specialization of distributional word representations with structured knowledge.
summary: Edoardo is a third-year Ph.D. student in Computational Linguistics at the University of Cambridge, where he is part of St John’s College. title: Edoardo M. Ponti

content: Emanuele is a first-year PhD student at the University of Copenhagen, supervised by Desmond Elliott and closely collaborating with Ryan. His research focuses on language grounding from multimodal and multilingual contexts. He also likes neural machine translation, typology and ramen.
summary: Emanuele is a first-year PhD student at the University of Copenhagen, supervised by Desmond Elliott and closely collaborating with Ryan. His research focuses on language grounding from multimodal and multilingual contexts. He also likes neural machine translation, typology and ramen.

content: Isabelle is an associate professor at the University of Copenhagen, Department of Computer Science and work in the general areas of Statistical Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning
summary: Isabelle is an associate professor at the University of Copenhagen, Department of Computer Science and work in the general areas of Statistical Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning
title: Isabelle Augenstein

content: Ekaterina Vylomova is a Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of Melbourne. She holds a PhD in Computer Science obtained from the University of Melbourne. Her research is focused on compositionality modelling for morphology, models for derivational morphology, neural machine translation, and diachronic language modeling.
summary: Ekaterina Vylomova is a Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of Melbourne. She holds a PhD in Computer Science obtained from the University of Melbourne. Her research is focused on compositionality modelling for morphology, models for derivational morphology, neural machine translation, and diachronic language modeling.

content: Ran is a first year PhD student at the University of Cambridge with Ryan. He is interested in research regarding gender bias in NLP systems and is picking up new interests as he goes along. While he waits for his systems to train he likes to play tennis and do stand-up comedy.
summary: Ran is a first year PhD student at the University of Cambridge with Ryan. He is interested in research regarding gender bias in NLP systems and is picking up new interests as he goes along. While he waits for his systems to train he likes to play tennis and do stand-up comedy.
title: Ran Zmigrod

summary: The study of linguistic typology is rooted in the implications we find between linguistic features, such as the fact that languages with object-verb word ordering tend to have postpositions. Uncovering such implications typically amounts to time-consuming manual processing by trained and experienced linguists, which potentially leaves key linguistic universals unexplored. In this paper, we present a computational model which successfully identifies known universals, including Greenberg universals, but also uncovers new ones, worthy of further linguistic investigation. Our approach outperforms baselines previously used for this problem, as well as a strong baseline from knowledge base population.
title: Uncovering Probabilistic Implications in Typological Knowledge Bases
